title: 108_hr3866
content: The Act titled "Anabolic Steroid Control Act of 2004" increases penalties for anabolic steroid offenses near sports facilities under the Controlled Substances Act. The Act "Anabolic Steroid Control Act of 2004" enhances penalties for anabolic steroid offenses near sports facilities by doubling the maximum punishment for manufacturing, distributing, or possessing with intent to distribute steroids within 1000 feet of a sports facility. The Act "Anabolic Steroid Control Act of 2004" increases penalties for steroid offenses near sports facilities by doubling the maximum punishment for possession with intent to distribute. The United States Sentencing Commission is tasked with reviewing and amending sentencing guidelines for anabolic steroid offenses to reflect their seriousness and deterrence. Additionally, amendments to the Controlled Substances Act are proposed. The Controlled Substances Act is amended to redefine the term 'anabolic steroid' to include specific hormonal substances related to testosterone, excluding certain other substances. The Controlled Substances Act is amended to redefine the term 'anabolic steroid' to include specific hormonal substances related to testosterone, excluding certain other substances such as androstenediol, androstenedione, bolasterone, boldenone, calusterone, and clostebol. The Controlled Substances Act redefines 'anabolic steroid' to include various hormonal substances related to testosterone, such as clostebol, dehydrochlormethyltestosterone, D1-dihydrotestosterone, 4-dihydrotestosterone, drostanolone, ethylestrenol, fluoxymesterone, formebolone, furazabol, 13a-ethyl-17b-hydroxygon-4-en-3-one, and 4-hydroxytestosterone. Amendments to the Act provide criteria for classification and recommendations from the Secretary of Health. Amendments to the Anabolic Steroids Control Act of 1990 include recommendations from the Secretary of Health to exempt certain anabolic steroid compounds from control if they do not pose a significant potential for abuse. The Secretary of Health and Human Services, in consultation with the Attorney General, must submit a report to Congress within 2 years of the Act's enactment. The report will evaluate health risks of dietary supplements containing substances similar to controlled substances and recommend whether they should be regulated as anabolic steroids.
